facts.text: Appellant is a limited company carrying on business in crushing sugarcane at Pipraich in Gorakhpur District from 1932.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a limited Company, which had been carrying on business in crushing sugarcane at a place called Pipraich in Gorakhpur District from the year 1932.

facts.text: In 1946, appellant decided to expand business, sold old machinery (160 tons/day capacity), purchased new one (650 tons capacity).

anchor.surface_text: In 1946 it decided to expand its business, and with that object, sold its old machinery which had a crushing capacity of 160 tons per day, and purchased a new one with 650 tons capacity.

facts.text: New plant installed in 1947, started working in 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: The new plant was installed in 1947, and it actually started working in 1948-49.

facts.text: Company sustained losses of Rs. 2,67,042-7-4 in 1948-49 and 1949-50 due to small sugarcane quota.

anchor.surface_text: with the result that in 1948-49 and 1949-50 the Company sustained losses which according to the appellant came to Rs. 2,67 042-7-4.

facts.text: On May 11, 1950, management wrote to Government to increase quota or permit sale of mills.

anchor.surface_text: After several unsuccessful attempts at setting a larger supply, the management wrote to the Government on May 11, 1950, either to increase their quota or to permit them to sell the Mills.

facts.text: In October 1950, Government granted permission for sale of plant and machinery.

anchor.surface_text: In October, 1950, the Government granted permission for the sale of the plant and machinery,

facts.text: Management sold plant and machinery to Madras party, leased back for current season.

anchor.surface_text: and pursuant thereto, the management sold them to a Madras party. As the crushing season was then on, the appellant obtained from the purchaser a lease of the Mills for the current season

facts.text: On December 26, 1950, union passed resolution to go on strike from January 12, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and they also passed a resolution on December 26, 1950, to go on strike from January 12, 1951, and companymunicated the same to the appellant.

facts.text: On January 3, 1951, Managing Director offered 25% of profit on sale if strike notice withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: On January 3, 1951, the Managing Director offered through the Manager of the Mills, to allot 25 per cent. of the profit on the sale transaction with the Madras party on certain terms

facts.text: Union replied on January 5, 1951, refusing to withdraw strike notice.

anchor.surface_text: To this, the reply of the Union on January 5, 1951, was as follows With reference to the assurance given by the Managing Director,

facts.text: Management replied on January 8, 1951, insisting on strike withdrawal.

anchor.surface_text: Replying to the objections raised by the respondent to some of the terms, the management wrote on January 8,1951, that they were ready to reconsider them,

facts.text: On January 10, 1951, General Manager wrote acceding to points if strike withdrawn, compensation not less than 1 lac.

anchor.surface_text: the General Manager wrote to the respondent on January 10, 1951, that in case the strike numberice was withdrawn at once he would accede to the following points

facts.text: No strike took place, crushing continued till end of January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: After this, the appellant did number hear from the respondent, the strike also did number take place, and the crushing went on till the end of January, 1951,

facts.text: On February 28, 1951, management issued notice discharging non-cooperating workers from March 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Hence it is numberified that workers who are number ready to companyorate they should companysider themselves to be discharged from 1st March 1951.

facts.text: Workers discharged from services since March 1, 1951, by notice dated March 14, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Now in pursuance of our numberice dated 28-2-1951, it is numberified that the following workers have been discharged from the services since 1-3-1951

facts.text: Date of termination extended to March 21, 1951, pending Government decision.

anchor.surface_text: that after the numberice dated March 14, 1951, was issued, Kashinath Pandey had a discussion with the management, as a result of which the date of termination

facts.text: Government declined to interfere with sale by letter dated March 21, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: But the Government declined by its letter dated March 21, 1951, to interfere with the sale of the machinery,

facts.text: Workers refused to cooperate in dismantling, management discharged them.

anchor.surface_text: and in accordance with the understanding reached above, the workers should have companyoperated with the appellant in dismantling the machinery from March 21. But they declined to do so,

facts.text: On April 1, 1951, purchaser concluded agreement with workmen for dismantling.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the inability of the appellant to take up the companytract, the purchaser entered into direct negotiations with the workmen, and on 1-4-1951 companycluded an agreement

facts.text: Appellant lost contract on which it would have earned profit of at least Rs. 2 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: The net result was that the appellant lost a companytract on which, as admitted by the respondent, it would have earned a profit of at least Rs. 2 lakhs.

facts.text: On November 16, 1951, U.P. Government issued notification under s.3 referring dispute to Industrial Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: the result was that on November 16,1951, the U. P. Government issued a numberification under section 3 of the U. P. Industrial Disputes Act XXVIII of 1947,

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal award dated February 28, 1952: closure bona fide, workmen conduct unfair, but promise binding, Rs.45,000 payable.

anchor.surface_text: By its award dated February 28,1952, the Indus- trial Tribunal held firstly that the closure of the business and the sale of the machinery by the appellant was bona fide,

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed award on July 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The management appealed against this decision but the same was companyfirmed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal by its order dated July 21, 1953.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: The matter number companyes before us. in appeal under art. 136.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no concluded binding agreement for 25% profits.

anchor.surface_text: It is impossible to hold on these facts that there was a companycluded agreement between the parties binding the appellant to give the workmen a share of the profits

issues.text: One of the points that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether on this correspondence there was a concluded and binding agreement that the appellant should pay 25 per cent. of the profits on the sale transaction to the workmen.

anchor.surface_text: After this, the appellant did number hear from the respondent, the strike also did number take place, and the crushing went on till the end of January, 1951, when the season came to an end. One of the points that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether on this correspondence there was a concluded. and binding agreement that the appellant should pay 25 per cent. of the profits on the sale transaction to the workmen.

issues.text: The notification dated November 16, 1951, referring the dispute to the adjudication of the Industrial Tribunal is ultra vires, and the reference and the award therein are in consequence void

anchor.surface_text: The matter number companyes before us. in appeal under art. 136. As the appeal raised questions of importance, and as the respondent was unrepresented we requested Mr. Umrigar to assist us, and we are indebted to him for his learned and comprehensive argument. Two contentions have been urged in support of the appeal The notification dated November 16, 1951, referring the dispute to the adjudication of the Industrial Tribunal is ultra vires, and the reference and the award therein are in consequence void and

issues.text: there was no concluded or binding agreement by the appellant to pay the workmen any share of profits in the sale transaction

anchor.surface_text: void and  2  there was numberconcluded or binding agreement by the appellant to pay the workmen any share of profits in the sale transaction and the award is therefore bad on the merits.

issues.text: the contention of the appellant is that it is a condition precedent to the exercise by the State of its power under s. 3 of the Act that there should be an industrial dispute, that there could be no industrial dispute according to this definition, unless there is a relationship of employer and employee that in the present case... there was no industrial dispute at the date of the notification on November 16, 1951, and that it was therefore incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: Taking the first contention, the provision of law under which the impugned notification dated November 16, 1951, was issued by the State is section 3 of the Act, which runs as follows If in the opinion of the State Government... Now, the contention of the appellant is that it is a condition precedent to the exercise by the State of its power under s. 3 of the Act that there should be an industrial dispute, that there could be no industrial dispute according to this definition, unless there is a relationship of employer and employee

issues.text: the power of the State to make a reference under section 3 will depend, according to the appellant, not only on the dispute having arisen in an existing industry but further, on the continued existence of that industry on the date of the notification.

anchor.surface_text: But it is argued for the appellant that even so, the notification dated November 16, 1951, would be incompetent as the industry had been closed before that date, and there was therefore no relationship of employer and employee at that point of time. In other words, the power of the State to make a reference under section 3 will depend, according to the appellant, not only on the dispute having arisen in an existing industry but further, on the continued existence of that industry on the -date of the notification.

issues.text: That brings us on to a consideration of the second question, as to whether there was a concluded agreement binding the appellant to pay 25 per cent. of the profits in the sale transaction to the workmen.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, as the claim for share of profits arose on January 3, 1951, and January 10, 1951, when the industry was working, the reference dated November 16, 1951, would be valid, notwithstanding that the business was closed on March 21, 1951. That brings us on to a consideration of the second question, as to whether there was a concluded agreement binding the appellant to pay 25 per cent. of the profits in. the sale transaction to the workmen.

issues.text: This contention assumes that the termination of the services of workmen, on the closure of a business, is retrenchment... whether the definition of retrenchment in section 2 oo of the Industrial Disputes Act XIV of 1947 is wide enough to include discharge subsequent on the closure of business

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended by Mr. Umrigar that even if there was no concluded agreement by the management to pay the workmen a share of profits on the sale transaction, it would have been open to the Tribunal to have awarded compensation for the termination of their services, treating it as retrenchment... This contention assumes that the termination of the services of workmen, on the closure of a business, is retrenchment. But retrenchment connotes in its ordinary acceptation that the business itself is being continued but that a portion of the staff or the labour force is discharged as surplusage... It is however contended by Mr. Umrigar that the definition of retrenchment in section 2 oo  of the Industrial Disputes Act XIV of 1947

holdings.text: The view that the industrial dispute to which the provisions of the Act apply is only one which arises out of an existing industry is clearly correct.

anchor.surface_text: The view therefore expressed in Indian Metal and Metallurgical Corporation v. Industrial Tribunal, Madras supra and K. N. Padmanabha Ayyar v. The State of Madras supra that the industrial dispute to which the provisions of the Act apply is only one which arises out of an existing industry is clearly correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms precedents that definition of industrial dispute presupposes continued existence of industry; scheme of Act applies to running industries.

holdings.text: Where the business has been closed and the closure is real and bona fide, any dispute arising with reference thereto would fall outside the purview of the Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, where the business has been closed and it is either admitted or found that the closure is real and bona fide, any dispute arising with reference thereto would, as held in K. N. Padmanabha Ayyar v. The State of Madras supra , fall outside the purview of the Industrial Disputes Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents; post-closure disputes between ex-employer/employees not covered if arising after bona fide closure.

holdings.text: The power of the State to make a reference under s.3 must be determined with reference not to the date on which it is made but to the date on which the right which is the subject-matter of the dispute arises.

anchor.surface_text: We think that on a true construction of s. 3, the power of the State to make a reference under that section must be determined with reference not to the date on which it is made but to the date on which the right which is the subject-matter of the dispute arises,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.3 imposes no requirement of existing industry at reference date; avoids anomalies like evading liability by closure.

holdings.text: It is impossible to hold on these facts that there was a concluded agreement between the parties binding the appellant to give the workmen a share of the profits of the sale transaction.

anchor.surface_text: It is impossible to hold on these facts that there was a concluded agreement between the parties binding the appellant to give the workmen a share of the profits

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offer conditional on strike withdrawal not accepted; no resolution or clear conduct acceptance; continued opposition and non-cooperation.

holdings.text: Retrenchment connotes that the business is being continued but a portion of labour force discharged as surplusage; termination of all on closure not retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: But retrenchment connotes in its ordinary acceptation that the business itself is being continued but that a portion of the staff or the labour force is discharged as surplusage and the termination of services of all the workmen as a result of the closure of the business cannot therefore be properly described as retrenchment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary meaning of term; distinguishes surplus discharge from total closure (obiter as not decided due to prospectivity).

holdings.text: The Industrial Disputes Amendment Act 1953 inserting s.2(oo) and s.25F has no retrospective operation.

anchor.surface_text: we have held in Messrs Burn and Co., Ltd., Calcutta v. Their Workmen supra that this Act has no retrospective operation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies precedent from Burn & Co.; rights determined by law at discharge date.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was of the opinion that, apart from agreement, the workmen should not, in view of their conduct, be awarded compensation, and we entirely agree with it.

anchor.surface_text: We should add that the Tribunal was of the opinion that, apart from agreement, the workmen should not, in view of their conduct, be awarded compensation, and we entirely agree with it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with tribunal finding on unfair conduct disentitling compensation; based on facts of non-cooperation.

precedents.citation: Indian Metal and Metallurgical Corporation v. Industrial Tribunal, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed in support of this position on the observation in Indian Metal and Metallurgical Corporation v. Industrial Tribunal, Madras 1 that the definition of an industrial dispute presupposes the continued existence of the industry, and on the decision in K. N. Padmanabha Ayyar v. The State of Madras 2 that there could be no industrial dispute with regard to a business, which was not in existence.

precedents.case_name: Indian Metal and Metallurgical Corporation v Industrial Tribunal Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: definition of an industrial dispute presupposes the continued existence of the industry
precedents.cited_holding: the definition of an industrial dispute presupposes the continued existence of the industry

precedents.citation: K. N. Padmanabha Ayyar v. The State of Madras 2

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed in support of this position on the observation in Indian Metal and Metallurgical Corporation v. Industrial Tribunal, Madras 1 that the definition of an industrial dispute presupposes the continued existence of the industry, and on the decision in K. N. Padmanabha Ayyar v. The State of Madras 2 that there could be no industrial dispute with regard to a business, which was not in existence. It cannot be doubted that the entire scheme of the Act assumes that there is in existence an industry,

precedents.case_name: K N Padmanabha Ayyar v The State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: no industrial dispute with regard to a business which was not in existence
precedents.cited_holding: there could be no industrial dispute with regard to a business, which was not in existence

precedents.citation: Messrs Burn and Co., Ltd., Calcutta v. Their Workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: In Messrs Burn and Co., Ltd., Calcutta v. Their Workmen 1 , this Court observed that the object of all labour legislation was firstly to ensure fair terms to the workmen, and secondly to prevent disputes between employers and employees, so that production might not be adversely affected and the larger interests of the public, might not suffer.

precedents.case_name: Messrs Burn and Co Ltd Calcutta v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: object of labour legislation is to ensure fair terms to workmen and prevent disputes so production not affected
precedents.cited_holding: the object of all labour legislation was firstly to ensure fair terms to the workmen, and secondly to prevent disputes between employers and employees, so that production might not be adversely affected and the larger interests of the public, might not suffer

The State of Madras supra that the industrial dispute to which the provisions of the Act apply is only one which arises out of an existing industry is clearly correct.

precedents.cited_proposition: industrial dispute arises out of an existing industry

precedents.citation: J. K. Hosiery Factory v. Labour Appellate Tribunal 1

anchor.surface_text: Our attention has been invited on behalf of the appellant to the decision in J. K. Hosiery Factory v. Labour Appellate Tribunal 1 , where it was held that retrenchment as defined in section 2 oo does not comprehend discharge on the closure of business, but Mr. Umrigar contends that it is erroneous.

precedents.case_name: J K Hosiery Factory v Labour Appellate Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: retrenchment as defined does not comprehend discharge on closure of business
precedents.cited_holding: retrenchment as defined in section 2 oo does not comprehend discharge on the closure of business

precedents.citation: Employees of Messrs India Reconstruction Corporation Limited, Calcutta v. Messrs India Reconstruction Corporation Limited, Calcutta 1

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended, on the strength of the decisions in Employees of Messrs India Reconstruction Corporation Limited, Calcutta v. Messrs India Reconstruction Corporation Limited, Calcutta 1 and Messrs Benett Coleman Company Ltd Their Employees 2 that even prior to the enactment of Act XLIII of 1953, the Tribunals had acted on the view that retrenchment included discharge on closure of business,

precedents.case_name: Employees of India Reconstruction Corporation Ltd Calcutta v India Reconstruction Corporation Ltd Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: retrenchment includes discharge on closure of business as difference is one of degree
precedents.cited_holding: Ordinarily retrenchment means discharge from service of only the surplus part of the labour force but in the case of closure the whole labour force is dispensed with. In substance the difference between closure and normal retrenchment is one of degree only.

precedents.citation: Messrs Benett Coleman Company Ltd Their Employees 2
